Title:
Convergent evolution of highly reduced fruiting bodies in
Pezizomycotina suggests key adaptations to the bee habitat
Keywords:
Ascosphaerales, Eremascaceae, honey bees, solitary bees,
yeasts, Skoua gen. nov.
Abstract:
Background. Among the understudied fungi are those found
in nature living in close association with bees (honey bees and solitary
bees). These fungi include three genera: Bettsia, Ascosphaera and
Eremascus which are remarkable not only for their specialized niche but
also for their simple fruiting bodies, or ascocarps which are
morphological anomalies in the Pezizomycotina. Bettsia and Ascosphaera
are characterized by a spore cyst, a unicellular cyst-like
cleistothecium. Eremascus is characterized by completely naked asci, or
asci not formed within a protective ascocarp. Until molecular
phylogenetics the placement of these genera within Pezizomycotina
remained tentative; they do not produce multicellular ascocarps, a
defining character of Pezizomycotina. Because of their unique fruiting
bodies, the close relationship of these bee-specialist fungi and their
monophyly appeared certain. However, recent phylogenetic studies based
on a single DNA locus indicated that Bettsia is not closely related to
Ascosphaera as previously thought. In this study, I isolated the very
rare fungus Eremascus fertilis (Ascomycota, Pezizomycotina) from the bee
bread of honey bees  these isolates represent the first report of E.
fertilis in nature. DNA was extracted from collections of E. fertilis
and Bettsia alvei and two nrDNA loci were sequenced in order to confirm
the phylogenetic position of these taxa. Results. Parsimony analysis of
DNA sequence data revealed that Eremascus is not monophyletic. Eremascus
albus remains closely related to Ascosphaera in Eurotiomycetes while E.
fertilis belongs in Leotiomycetes. The data confirm that Bettsia is not
closely related to Ascosphaera and like E. fertilis belongs in
Leotiomycetes. These results indicate that both the naked ascus and
spore cyst evolved twice in the Pezizomycotina and in distantly related
lineages. The new genus Skoua is described to accommodate E. fertilis.
Conclusions. The naked ascus and spore cyst are shown to have evolved
convergently, both times within the bee habitat. The convergent
evolution of these unique ascocarps within the bee habitat is revealed
to be adaptive for dispersal. Elucidating the dispersal strategies of
these fungal symbionts contributes to our understanding of their
interaction with bees and to the factors driving the evolution of
reduced ascocarps in Pezizomycotina.
